message.content:
There are several verb tenses in English grammar. These tenses help in expressing actions and events that occur at specific points in time. Some of the main verb tenses include:

1. Present Tense: This tense is used to describe habits, routines, general truths, and things that happen regularly or are always true. For example, "I eat breakfast every day."

2. Past Tense: This tense is used to describe actions or events that occurred in the past. For example, "I ate breakfast yesterday."

3. Future Tense: This tense is used to describe planned actions or events that will happen in the future. For example, "I will eat breakfast tomorrow."

4. Present Perfect Tense: This tense is used to describe actions or events that started in the past and continue up to the present or have just been completed. For example, "I have eaten breakfast today."

5. Past Perfect Tense: This tense is used to describe actions or events that occurred before another past action or event. For example, "I had eaten my breakfast before I left for work."

6. Future Perfect Tense: This tense is used to describe actions or events that will have been completed by a specific time in the future. For example, "By tomorrow, I will have eaten all of my dinners."

7. Present Continuous (also called Present Progressive) Tense: This tense is used to describe ongoing actions or events happening right now. For example, "I am eating breakfast at the moment."

8. Past Continuous (also called Past Progressive) Tense: This tense is used to describe actions or events that were happening just before another past action or event. For example, "I was eating breakfast when you called me."

9. Future Continuous (also called Future Progressive) Tense: This tense is used to describe actions or events that will be ongoing at a specific time in the future. For example, "By tomorrow, I will be eating all of my dinners."
